page.title: 4.2.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will be introduced to function notation as a more concise and precise way to represent functions. Further, you will learn about the relationship between input and output.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Use function notation to express functions that have specific inputs and outputs.
  • Explain what function notation is and why it exists.
  • Explain a statement written in function notation in terms of a situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 4.2.1: Interpreting Graphs to Answer Questions
  • 4.2.2: Interpreting Statements Written in Function Notation
    • 4.2.2: Self Check
    • 4.2.2: Additional Resources
  • 4.2.3: Finding a Unique Output for Each Input
    • 4.2.3: Self Check
    • 4.2.3: Additional Resources
  • 4.2.4: Understanding Function Notation Using Application Problems

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 4.2.5: Practice
  • 4.2.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 4.2.1: Interpreting Graphs to Answer Questions
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Here are the graphs of some situations you saw before. Each graph represents the distance of a dog from a post as a function of time since the dog owner left to purchase something from a store. Distance is measured in feet, and time is measured in seconds.

Day 2

page.title: 4.2.2: Interpreting Statements Written in Function Notation
page.contents:
Activity

Let’s name the functions that relate the dog’s distance from the post and the time since its owner left: function \(f\) for Day 1, function \(g\) for Day 2, function \(h\) for Day 3. The input of each function is time in seconds, \(t\).

Day 1


Day 2


Day 3

Day 1

Day 2

Day 3

  1. Describe what each expression represents in this context:
    1. \(f(15)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(f(15)\) is the distance from the post 15 seconds after the owner left on Day 1.



    1. \(g(48)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(g(48)\) is the distance from the post 48 seconds after the owner left on Day 2.



    1. \(h(t)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(h(t)\) is the distance from the post \(t\) seconds after the owner left on Day 3.



  1. Describe what each expression represents in this context:
    1. \(h(40)=4.6\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

On the third day, 40 seconds after the owner left, the dog was 4.6 feet away from the post.



    1. \(f(t)=5\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

On the first day, \(t\) seconds after the owner left, the dog was 5 feet away from the post.



    1. \(g(t) = d\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

On the second day, \(t\) seconds after the owner left, the dog was \(d\) feet away from the post.


Video: Interpreting Function Notation

Watch the following video to learn more about function notation.

page.title: 4.2.2: Self Check
page.contents: A function \(f(y) = N\) gives the number of police officers, \(N\), in a town in year \(y\). What does \(f(2005)=300\) represent?

answer.answer_text: After 2005 years, there were 300 police officers.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 2005 is the year, not the number of years. The answer is: In the year 2005, there were 300 police officers.

answer.answer_text: At year 300, there were 2005 police officers.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 300 is the output, not the input. The answer is: In the year 2005, there were 300 police officers.

answer.answer_text: In the year 2005, there were 300 police officers.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The input into the function, \(f\), is 2005, and the output is 300.

answer.answer_text: In the year 2005, there were 300 more police officers than in 2004.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The output is the number of police officers in the year 2005, not the increase in the number of officers. The answer is: In the year 2005, there were 300 police officers.

page.title: 4.2.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Understanding Function Notation

Using Function Notation

Once we determine that a relationship is a function, we need to display and define the functional relationships so that we can understand and use them, and sometimes also so that we can program them into computers. There are various ways of representing functions. A standard function notation is one representation that facilitates working with functions.

To represent “height is a function of age,” we start by identifying the descriptive variables \(h\) for height and \(a\) for age. The letters \(f\), \(g\), and \(h\) are often used to represent functions, just as we use \(x\), \(y\), and \(z\) to represent numbers and \(A\), \(B\), and \(C\) to represent sets.

  • \(h\) is \(f\) of \(a\): We name the function \(f\); height is a function of age.
  • \(h=f(a)\): We use parentheses to indicate the function input.
  • \(f(a)\): We name the function \(f\); the expression is read as “\(f\) of \(a\).”

Remember, we can use any letter to name the function; the notation \(h(a)\) shows us that \(h\) depends on \(a\). The value \(a\) must be put into the function \(h\) to get a result. The parentheses indicate that age is input into the function; they do not indicate multiplication.

We can also give an algebraic expression as the input to a function. For example, \(f(a+b)\)  means “first add \(a\) and \(b\), and the result is the input for the function \(f\).” The operations must be performed in this order to obtain the correct result.

Function Notation

The notation \(y=f(x)\) defines a function named \(f\). This is read as “\(y\) is a function of \(x\).” The letter \(x\) represents the input value, or independent variable. The letter \(y\), or \(f(x)\), represents the output value, or dependent variable.


Example: Using Function Notation for Days in a Month

Use function notation to represent a function whose input is the name of a month and output is the number of days in that month (don’t include leap years).


For example, \(f\)(March)\(=31\), because March has 31 days. The notation \(d=f(m)\) reminds us that the number of days, \(d\) (the output), is dependent on the name of the month, \(m\) (the input).

Analysis

Note that the inputs to a function do not have to be numbers; function inputs can be names of people, labels of geometric objects, or any other element that determines some kind of output. However, most of the functions we will work with in this course will have numbers as inputs and outputs.

Try It: Understanding Function Notation


Use function notation to express the weight of a pig, \(W\), in pounds as a function of its age in days, \(d\).

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to express this situation in function notation:

\(W=f(d)\). The pig’s weight is a function of the age of the pig in days.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.2.3: Finding a Unique Output for Each Input
page.contents:
Activity

Rule B takes a person’s name as its input and gives their birthday as the output.

Input

Output

Abraham Lincoln

February 12







Rule P takes a date as its input and gives a person with that birthday as the output.

Input

Output

August 26

Katherine Johnson










  1. Complete each table with three more examples of input-output pairs.

Enter your answers here for the table using Rule B:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Input: Alexander Hamilton, Output: January 11
Input: Frida Kahlo, Output: July 6
Input: Rosa Parks, Output: February 4



Enter your answers here for the table using Rule P:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Input: March 14 , Output: Albert Einstein
Input: April 25, Output: Ella Fitzgerald
Input: October 17, Output: Mae Jemison



  1. If you use your name as the input to B, how many outputs are possible? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer

One possible output. I only have one birthday.



  1. If you use your birthday as the input to P, how many outputs are possible? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Many possible outputs. There are other people whose birthday is the same as mine.



  1. Only one of the two relationships is a function. The other is not a function. Which one is which? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

B is a function, and P is not. B assigns only one output to the input.



  1. For the relationship that is a function, write two input-output pairs from the table using function notation.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

  • \(B\)(Abraham Lincoln) = February 12
  • \(B\)(Frida Kahlo) = July 6


Extending Your Thinking

  1. Write a rule that describes these input-output pairs:
    \(F\)(ONE) \(=3\)
    \(F\)(TWO) \(=3\)
    \(F\)(THREE) \(=5\)
    \(F\)(FOUR) \(=4\)

    What rule could define function \(F\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Function \(F\) takes a word for its input and gives the number of letters in that word for its output.


  1. Here are some input-output pairs with the same inputs but different outputs:
    \(v\)(ONE) \(=2\)
    \(v\)(TWO) \(=1\)
    \(v\)(THREE) \(=2\)
    \(v\)(FOUR) \(=2\)

    What rule could define function \(v\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Function \(v\) takes a word for its input and gives the number of vowels in that word as its output.

page.title: 4.2.3: Self Check
page.contents:
The price for pizzas, in dollars, is a function of the number of pizzas bought, \(n\). Identify the input, output, and meaning of the statement:

\(p(11)=55\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The meaning is correct, but the input and output are not correct. The input is the number of pizzas. The answer is: Input: 11, Output: 55, 11 pizzas cost $55.
That’s correct! Check yourself: The price depends on the number of pizzas bought.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The input and output are switched, and the meaning statement is also switched. The input is the number of pizzas. The answer is: Input: 11, Output: 55, 11 pizzas cost $55.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The input and output are correct, but the meaning statement is not correct. The answer is: Input: 11, Output: 55, 11 pizzas cost $55.

page.title: 4.2.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Meanings in Functions

Review the following examples to help you gain a better understanding of meanings in functions.

Example 1

The number of cubic yards of dirt, \(D\), needed to cover a garden with an area of \(a\) square feet is given by \(D=g(a)\).

  1. A garden with area 5000 \(ft^2\) requires 50 \(yd^3\) of dirt. Express this information in terms of the function \(g\).
    Solution: \(g(5000)=50\)

  2. Explain the meaning of the statement \(g(100)=1\).
    Solution: The number of cubic yards of dirt required for a garden of 100 square feet is 1.

Example 2

Let \(f(t)\) be the number of ducks in a lake \(t\) years after 1990. Explain the meaning of each statement:

  1. \(f(5)=30\)
    Solution: In 1995 (5 years after 1990), there were 30 ducks in the lake.

  2. \(f(10)=40\)
    Solution: In 2000 (10 years after 1990), there were 40 ducks in the lake.

Try It: Meanings in Functions

The amount of garbage, \(G\), produced by a city with population \(p\) is given by \(G=f(p)\). \(G\) is measured in tons per week, and \(p\) is measured in thousands of people.

  1. The town of Tola has a population of 40,000 and produces 13 tons of garbage each week. Express this information in terms of the function \(f\).
  2. Explain the meaning of the statement \(f(5)=2\).

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to determine the meaning of a function in function notation:

  1. \(13=f(40)\)
  2. Five thousand people will produce 2 tons of garbage each week.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.2.4: Understanding Function Notation Using Application Problems
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Function \(Q\) gives a puppy’s weight, in pounds, as a function of its age, in months.


  1. What does each expression or equation represent in this situation?

    1. \(Q(18)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

The weight of the puppy when it was 18 months old



    1. \(Q(30)=27.5\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

When the puppy was 30 months old, it weighed 27.5 pounds.



  1. Use function notation to represent each statement.

    1. When the puppy turned 12 months old, it weighed 19.6 pounds.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(Q(12)=19.6\)



    1. When the puppy was \(m\) months old, it weighed \(w\) pounds.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(Q(m)=w\)

page.title: 4.2.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. The height of water in a bathtub, \(w\), is a function of time, \(t\). Let \(P\) represent this function. Height is measured in inches and time in minutes.

  1. \(P(0) = 0\)

Correct! The bathtub starts out with no water.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the bathtub starts out with no water. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(P(4) = 10\)

Correct! The height of the water is 10 inches after 4 minutes.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the height of the water is 10 inches after 4 minutes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(P(10) = 4\)

Correct! After 10 minutes, the height of the water is 4 inches.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the height of the water is 10 inches after 4 minutes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(P(20) = 0\)

Correct! After 20 minutes, the bathtub is empty.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: After 20 minutes, the bathtub is empty. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Function \(C\) takes time for its input and gives a student’s Monday class for its output.

    Use function notation to represent: A student has English at 10:00.

Correct! \(C(10:00)=English\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.2.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(C(10:00)=English\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Function \(f\) gives the distance of a dog from a post, in feet, as a function of time, in seconds, since its owner left.

  1. Find the value of \(f(20)\).

Correct! \(f(20)=3.1\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(f(20)=3.1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the value of \(f(140)\).

Correct! \(f(140)=3.5\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(f(140)=3.5\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  1. Looking at the graph below, what does the point \((1980, 80)\) mean?



Correct! In 1980, the world population increased by 80 million people.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.2.1–4.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: In 1980, the world population increased by 80 million people. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Function \(R\) gives the number of inches of rain after \(h\) hours. What does the statement \(R(6)=5\) mean?

Correct! After 6 hours, there was 5 inches of rain.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.2.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is after 6 hours, there was 5 inches of rain. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Function R gives the number of inches, T, of rain after h, hours. Choose which function notation represents this situation.

Correct! \(T=R(h)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(T=R(h)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Use function notation to represent that the number of miles, \(m\), a car travels as a function of time, \(t\).

Correct! \(m=f(t)\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.2.2–4.2.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(m=f(t)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 4.2.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Use function notation to express functions that have specific inputs and outputs.
  • Explain what function notation is and why it exists.
  • Explain a statement written in function notation in terms of a situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 4.2.1: Interpreting Graphs to Answer Questions
    • In this activity, you used graphs to answer questions and also interpreted points on graphs to answer questions.
  • 4.2.2: Interpreting Statements Written in Function Notation
    • In this activity, you used function notation to represent different situations. You identified the inputs for the functions as they changed.
  • 4.2.2: Self Check
  • 4.2.3: Finding a Unique Output for Each Input
    • In this activity, you identified inputs and outputs given rules. You determined if the inputs and outputs created a function.
  • 4.2.3: Self Check
  • 4.2.4: Understanding Function Notation Using Application Problems
    • In this activity, you read function notation in terms of the situation. You also wrote function notation to represent the given situation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 4.2.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
